Scientists believe these measurements may require reevaluation due to doubts over their accuracy. In recent weeks, extreme heat across much of North America — including severe wildfires caused by dry lightning strikes—had become normal. But now there could come a long break between them. Global average surface air temperature rose less than half what climate models predicted back when world leaders agreed to limit warming to “well below” levels deemed dangerously damaging – which suggests we aren’t doing enough fast enough to keep things under control. That doesn’t mean every prediction turned out wrong; rather, more research shows why certain predictions didn’t hold true while many did. For instance, researchers found evidence pointing toward increased rainfall coming midway through future summers if greenhouse gas emissions remain constant instead of decreasing according to projections based upon those same factors alone. This makes sense given how wet parts of Europe got recently despite having no change compared elsewhere globally. When thinking ahead though, one thing remains clear regarding our changing atmosphere: even small increases can lead us down unexpected paths leading towards greater extremes!
